VOL. XXIX, No. 50
CLASS PROJECTS
THREE
PLANNED AT SENIOR
MEETING FRIDAY
Graduating Class Plans Worthy Memorial. Portraits May Be Presented.
Dues Well Paid

In order to leave a worthy memorial of the class of '25, its committee presented three plans at a
meeting in M. E. 110 on Friday,
April 24. Kelso Morrill, chairman, said that these suggestions
will be voted on at the next class
meeting.
Funds for the first plan would
be raised by an insurance or
endowment policy. Seventy-five
per cent. of the men in the class
would be needed to subscribe if it
is to be a success. The result of
a small premium, paid each year,
would amount 'to $25,000 in a
specified time. If the new Undergraduate Plan is adopted, this SUM
might be used to establish a scholarship to enable a man to enter
Johns Hopkins for advanced work.
If, however, the plan is not adopted; the entire sum might be turned
over to the University Fund.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE. MD., APRIL 28, 1925

PI DELTA EPSILON
ADMITS TWELVE
Twelve men were admitted
to Pi Delta Epsilon at the
spring elections of the Honorary Journalistic Fraternity.
All of these men are active in
campus publications, either the
NEWS-LETTER, Black and Blue
Jay, or Hullabaloo. The list
is as follows:
Ludlow Baldwin, '26, Bateman Draper, 26, Risley Ensor, '26, Philip Sachs, '25,
Chauncey Tatum, '25, Robert
Wienefeld, '25, Pendleton
Herring, '25, LeRoy Miller,
'26, Jackson Kidd, '26, Thornley
Martin, '26, George
Snoops, '26, and Roger Shaw,
'25.
The initiation ceremonies
will be held on Thursday
night, May 7.

PHI BETA KAPPA SOCIETY
ELECTION COMPLETED
AT MEETING
Nineteen Elected from Graduate and
Undergraduate Scholars Who
Have Excelled

Nineteen students were elected
to the Alpha Chapter of the Phi
Beta Kappa last Thursday, April
23, in Gilman Hall, at the annual
meeting of the fraternity. Members were appointed from the academic undergraduate body and
from the graduate students of Philosophy and of Medicine.
Those of the collegiate group
who have gained distinction are:
George Brewer, A. S. Dryden, A.
L. Grafflin, G. B. Hess, M. B.
Kirsh, Sidney Musher, J. U. Noble, G. K. Reiblick, M. T. Sonneborn and R. H. Wienefeld.

FRENCH PROFESSOR GIVES
ENGINEERING LECTURES
Third Talk on Automobile Adjustment
Proves Most Interesting

Professar Pierre Lemaire, assistant director of the Lyons Central
School, has been giving a series of
four lectures on "The Silk Industry in Lyons," "The School of Technology at Lyons," "The Design and
Proper Adjustment of Automobile
Parts," and "Color Photography."
Dr. Lemaire Speaks
The third lecture, given in Room
110, M. E., last Thursday, was more
interesting than the others. In it
Dr. Lemaire spoke of the vibrations
caused by the shock of an automobile's passing over the rough surface of a road. There was a point,

JUNE WEEK PLANS PRACTICALLY
COMPLETED, SAYS W. C. GARDNER
Plans for the 1925 June Week
have been practically completed,
according to . W. Carville Gardner, chairman of the committee.
The "secret" as to what these
plans are will be entirely divulged in the near future.
When the committee has
worked out the complete schedule, copies of it will be placed in
each students' post office box. Although the committee has been

Felix writes from—

Yet the men fortunate to know'
all about it merely grin and look
pleased. They claim it is a new
wrinkle for June Weeks and has
never been done before, that everybody will like it, and they usually conclude by saying with
great aplomb that it is sure to
be "damn good !"
Whatever the secret may be,
final plans for it are expected to
be completed in the near future,
and will be divulged by next Friday.

Ho for the land of Cheese, Chocolate, and yodels! We went alping
first thing this morning among the
foothills to get in condition for the
Olympic's Yodeling contest day
after tomorrow. Imagine representing our country in such a famous
international tilt!
I put the finishing touches on a
new crescendo -profundo yodel
with which we hope to carry the
field. Jack is acting as my allround manager,rubber, and trainer
and I have to give him credit in
spite of our spat over Kitty.
This is a beautiful country, old
feline, but you can't help but notice
how the advertisers have slipped up
on a wonderful opportunity to cover
the mountainsides.
Yours in Mu Mu,

VOL. XXIX, No. 50
CLASS PROJECTS
THREE
PLANNED AT SENIOR
MEETING FRIDAY
Graduating Class Plans Worthy Memorial. Portraits May Be Presented.
Dues Well Paid

In order to leave a worthy memorial of the class of '25, its committee presented three plans at a
meeting in M. E. 110 on Friday,
April 24. Kelso Morrill, chairman, said that these suggestions
will be voted on at the next class
meeting.
Funds for the first plan would
be raised by an insurance or
endowment policy. Seventy-five
per cent. of the men in the class
would be needed to subscribe if it
is to be a success. The result of
a small premium, paid each year,
would amount 'to $25,000 in a
specified time. If the new Undergraduate Plan is adopted, this SUM
might be used to establish a scholarship to enable a man to enter
Johns Hopkins for advanced work.
If, however, the plan is not adopted; the entire sum might be turned
over to the University Fund.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE. MD., APRIL 28, 1925

PI DELTA EPSILON
ADMITS TWELVE
Twelve men were admitted
to Pi Delta Epsilon at the
spring elections of the Honorary Journalistic Fraternity.
All of these men are active in
campus publications, either the
NEWS-LETTER, Black and Blue
Jay, or Hullabaloo. The list
is as follows:
Ludlow Baldwin, '26, Bateman Draper, 26, Risley Ensor, '26, Philip Sachs, '25,
Chauncey Tatum, '25, Robert
Wienefeld, '25, Pendleton
Herring, '25, LeRoy Miller,
'26, Jackson Kidd, '26, Thornley
Martin, '26, George
Snoops, '26, and Roger Shaw,
'25.
The initiation ceremonies
will be held on Thursday
night, May 7.

PHI BETA KAPPA SOCIETY
ELECTION COMPLETED
AT MEETING
Nineteen Elected from Graduate and
Undergraduate Scholars Who
Have Excelled

Nineteen students were elected
to the Alpha Chapter of the Phi
Beta Kappa last Thursday, April
23, in Gilman Hall, at the annual
meeting of the fraternity. Members were appointed from the academic undergraduate body and
from the graduate students of Philosophy and of Medicine.
Those of the collegiate group
who have gained distinction are:
George Brewer, A. S. Dryden, A.
L. Grafflin, G. B. Hess, M. B.
Kirsh, Sidney Musher, J. U. Noble, G. K. Reiblick, M. T. Sonneborn and R. H. Wienefeld.

ENGINEERING LECTURES
Third Talk on Automobile Adjustment
Proves Most Interesting

Professar Pierre Lemaire, assistant director of the Lyons Central
School, has been giving a series of
four lectures on "The Silk Industry in Lyons," "The School of Technology at Lyons," "The Design and
Proper Adjustment of Automobile
Parts," and "Color Photography."
Dr. Lemaire Speaks

110, M. E., last Thursday, was more
interesting than the others. In it
Dr. Lemaire spoke of the vibrations
caused by the shock of an automobile's passing over the rough surface of a road. There was a point,

JUNE WEEK PLANS PRACTICALLY
COMPLETED, SAYS W. C. GARDNER
Plans for the 1925 June Week
have been practically completed,
according to . W. Carville Gardner, chairman of the committee.
The "secret" as to what these
plans are will be entirely divulged in the near future.
When the committee has
worked out the complete schedule, copies of it will be placed in
each students' post office box. Although the committee has been

Felix writes from—

Yet the men fortunate to know'
all about it merely grin and look
pleased. They claim it is a new
wrinkle for June Weeks and has
never been done before, that everybody will like it, and they usually conclude by saying with
great aplomb that it is sure to
be "damn good !"
Whatever the secret may be,
final plans for it are expected to
be completed in the near future,
and will be divulged by next Friday.

Ho for the land of Cheese, Chocolate, and yodels! We went alping
first thing this morning among the
foothills to get in condition for the
Olympic's Yodeling contest day
after tomorrow. Imagine representing our country in such a famous
international tilt!
I put the finishing touches on a
new crescendo -profundo yodel
with which we hope to carry the
field. Jack is acting as my allround manager,rubber, and trainer
and I have to give him credit in
spite of our spat over Kitty.
This is a beautiful country, old
feline, but you can't help but notice
how the advertisers have slipped up
on a wonderful opportunity to cover
the mountainsides.
Yours in Mu Mu,
